## ğŸŒ EFA vs. CFA: whatâ€™s the difference?
There are two types of factor analysis:

#### Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA)
CFA is used when you already have a theory or hypothesis. Youâ€™re basically asking, â€œDoes my data support the structure I expect?â€ You test whether the model you believe in can be reproduced using your observed data.

#### Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA)
EFA is used when you donâ€™t have a strong theory yet. You explore the data to see how many factors best explain the relationships among your observed variables. Itâ€™s like asking: â€œWhat structure naturally emerges from these items?â€

For example, imagine personality research didnâ€™t exist yet. You write a ton of items that describe different behaviors and attitudes. You donâ€™t know how many dimensions of personality there are, or what they are. You run EFA to see which items â€œhang together,â€ and maybe you discover several clusters of items. You then interpret and name those clustersâ€”maybe you end up with something like Oppenness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.

Mathematically, EFA is asking:
Can a smaller number of underlying factors explain the variance and correlations we see in these measured variables?

Itâ€™s really just statistics doing what it always does: trying to explain variation.

- [ANOVA]{style="font-weight: bold;"}: do different groups explain variance in an outcome?
- [Regression]{style="font-weight: bold;"}: do predictors explain variance in an outcome?
- [EFA]{style="font-weight: bold;"}: do latent factors explain variance in many observed variables?
Same logicâ€”different target.

## ğŸ™‰ So where does PCA come in, and why is it a problem?

Another technique commonly used in our field is Principal Components Analysis (PCA). It looks very similar to EFA, so similar that software (like SPSS) puts them under the same menu. Unfortunately, this causes a lot of researchers to confuse the two and accidentally use PCA when they meant to use EFA.

And the problem is widespread:
In a review of two measurement journals across six years, 64% of papers used PCA, while only 33% used EFA (Osborne et al., 2008). PCA is simply easier to click, so people default to it even when itâ€™s not appropriate.
Letâ€™s get clear about the difference.

## ğŸ¤” What makes them fundamentally different: the mathematical assumption

The major difference is how each method treats variance:

#### EFA

- The diagonal of the covariance matrix < 1
- Because variance is split into shared and unique parts
- The diagonal only contains shared variance (communalities)
- Meaning: EFA assumes variables have unique variance and measurement error

#### PCA

- The diagonal is constrained to be 1
- Meaning it assumes each variableâ€™s entire variance is shared with all other variables (aka items)
- No measurement error, no unique variance
- This is almost never true in real data

This is why PCA is not good for theory building. It doesnâ€™t model latent constructs. It doesnâ€™t account for measurement error. It just compresses variables.

#### Use EFA when

#### Use PCA when

- You purely want to reduce the number of variables
- You donâ€™t care about underlying constructs
- You want to avoid multicollinearity
- You want fewer predictors for machine learning models
- Youâ€™re trying to simplify a large dataset

PCA is great for data prepâ€”but not for understanding psychological constructs.


## ğŸ§  Final Thoughts

EFA and PCA look similar, but they answer completely different questions. When we mix them up, we unintentionally do bad scienceâ€”not because we want to, but because the software makes it too easy to click the wrong thing.
